question: Question_05_(d)
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}

Let

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
y=f(x)=6x^{1/5}+x^{6/5}\end{align*}\\ Find the intervals on which \emph{y=f(x)} is
concave up.
sols:
From
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH100/December 2011/Question 5 (c)}{part
(c)}, we know that

\begin{align*}
f''(x) &= \frac{6(x-4)}{25x^{9/5}}\end{align*}

Notice that the potential inflection points are at \emph{x}=0,4, where
$f''(x)$ is either zero or undefined. Doing a sign chart for this
function yields the following. When \emph{x \textless{} 0} we have that
$f''(x) > 0$. When $0 < x < 4$ we have that $f''(x) < 0$. When $x > 4$
we have that $f''(x) > 0$. Hence, the function is concave up on
$(-\infty, 0) \cup (4,\infty)$.

\emph{Note: Since the sign of $f''(x)$ changes at both points, both
$x=0$ and $x=4$ are inflection points. Even though $f''(x)$ is not
defined at $x = 0$.}
hints:
We already computed the second derivative in
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH100/December 2011/Question 5 (c)}{part
(c)}. Checking where this is positive tells you when your function is
concave up.
